title: How To Introduce A New Hen To The Hen House

tasks.task: Introducing a new hen to an existing flock in a hen house.
subtasks: Place the new hen in a large wire dog crate.
Position the crate within the chicken run so the existing hens can see the new arrival.
Allow the existing hens to observe the new hen for three days while confining the new hen to the crate to reduce initial aggression.
Once the existing hens have lost interest, open the crate door and allow the new hen to exit when she is ready.

tasks.task: Alternatively, introduce the new hen to the hen house in darkness, closing the door until the hen wakes up to minimize notice by the existing flock.
Preparing a chicken for integration with an existing flock.
subtasks: Ensuring the new chicken is free from illness or parasites before introduction.
Gradually familiarizing the new chicken with the existing flock before full integration, if possible.
Positioning the crate near areas where chickens congregate to increase exposure.
Monitoring interactions and intervening if necessary to prevent serious aggression.

tasks.task: Ensuring the safety of new males (e.g., Mr. Brown) in the flock.
subtasks: Using a dog crate to contain the new male initially to protect from flock aggression.
Allowing gradual integration by enabling safe interaction, such as observing each other through fencing.
Providing alternative escape routes or gathering areas for new additions to avoid direct confrontation.
